Checklist.Question: Are interim changes incorporated and/or canceled on the interim change summary page in the NATOPS U.S. Navy Aircraft Rescue and Firefighting manuals?Are sufficient EFR/ARFF personnel assigned to perform all administrative and operational functions?

Does the EFR/ARFF unit maintain an active airworthiness account in order to ensure the most updated NATOPS US. Navy Aircraft Rescue and Firefighting manuals 00-80R-14; 00-80R-14-1; 00-80R-20 are being utilized?

Are the required EFR/ARFF Ready Reference publications readily  available as required: Naval Ships’ Technical Manual (NSTM), Chapter 555, Shipboard Firefighting; Aerospace Emergency Rescue and Mishap Response Information (Emergency Services) — Air Force Technical Order 00-105E-9; Aircraft Signals NATOPS Manual (NAVAIR 00-80T-113); NAWCWPDNDIV CHINA LAKE Insensitive Munitions?
Has the unit completed the following documents: risk assessment, standard of cover, self-assessment, and strategic plan?
Checklist.Reference: MCO 11000.11, chap 2, par 1, DoDI 6055.06, chap 5, par 6.2.1 and E3.5

Checklist.Question: Are automated Marine Corps Fire Incident Reporting System (MCFIRS) reports submitted for each reportable event within 60 days as required?
Is a daily journal kept on file for a period of three years?
When required to man the immediate response alert position, are EFR/ARFF personnel assigned no more than 8 total hours in any one 24-hour period?

Does the units standard operating procedure address rehabilitation operations procedures/processes for EFR/ARFF members during incident scene operations, post incidents and training events? Does the rehabilitation plan address the resourcing of support required to perform rehabilitation operations.
Does the units Standard Operating Procedures establish specific rules, regulations, and procedures relating to the operation of EFR/ARFF vehicles operating in emergency and standard driving mode?
Does the EFR/ARFF unit have a written safety and health program?

In the event of an exposure to a hazardous material does the EFR/ARFF unit provide the physician with an exposure report that contains a description of the EFR/ARFF Marines duties while being exposed, level of anticipated exposure level, and a description of PPE used?
Is a permanent all-weather training ground for actual burn practice and simulated emergency operations available?
Does the training program include training fires and realistic forcible entry into and rescue from burning aircraft?
Are live firefighting/ rescue drills being conducted to ensure the proficiency and experience level of rescue personnel is maintained?
Are driver/operators of emergency vehicles properly licensed to include current drivers’ physicals and EVOC training?
Does the Commander or Expeditionary Airfield Fire and Emergency Services Officer of aircraft rescue and firefighting budget for training funds?
Is the ARFF unit cross-trained and mutually supporting with the structural fire branch?
Are 7051/7002 assigned personnel being trained IAW the applicable and approved T&R syllabi?
Are all deferrals that are authorized by the unit commanding officer and documented?
Are deferred events manually updated in M- SHARP?

Are event evaluations conducted after each training event to record accomplishments of training goals, identify short-falls, and adjust training priorities. Are these results being documented using the EFR/ARFF T&R Syllabus Evaluation Form?
Checklist.Reference: NAVMC 3500.14C, chap 2, par 206.1, NAVMC 3500.114, chap 2, par 2.7.4

Checklist.Question: Are completed evaluation forms maintained in the Marines’ Individual Performance Records?
Are Individual Performance Record audits and updates conducted when individuals report to a unit, annually within 30 days of birthday, and upon transfer from a unit?
Are all individual T&R certifications, qualifications and designations properly documented in the Individual Performance Records, logged in to M-SHARP, and monitored for currency?
Is the proficiency status of individual core and mission skills, maintained and monitored in M-SHARP to ensure proper scheduling and/or logging of required event training?
Does the unit maintain at least one trained representative who has successfully completed the M-SHARP administrators’ course?
Does the EFR/ARFF unit ensure EFR/ARFF personnel have obtained the certification levels required per DoD 6055.06-M Table C2.T1?
Checklist.Reference: DoD 6055.06-M, chap 2, table C2.T1, NAVMC 3500.114, chap 1, table 1.12

Checklist.Question: Does the EFR/ARFF unit possess, or have access to, the equipment, computers, publications, supplies, and training aids necessary to conduct required knowledge training and performance evaluations?
Are the current editions of the following training directives and references available to support the unit’s training efforts?
Checklist.Reference: DoDI 6055.06, DoD F&ES Program; DoD 6055.06-M, DoD F&ES Certification Program; DoD F&ES Certification Program Procedural Guide

Checklist.Question: Has at least one CerTest Program Manager been appointed in writing; Does the appointment letter state “all managers have read and understand all program requirements listed in the DoD FFCS Certification System Procedural and Policy Guide; and has a copy of this letter must been forwarded to the DoD Administration Center?
Checklist.Reference: DoD F&ES Certification Program Procedural Guide, chap 3, attach 2

Checklist.Question: Does the EFR/ARFF unit ensure all evaluations are carried out according to required procedures and guidelines?
Checklist.Reference: DoD 6055.06-M, chap 3, par C3.3.2, C3.4 through C3.5., DoD DoD F&ES Certification Program Procedural Guide, chap 4, par 4.3,4.3.6, chap 7, par 7.2.2, 7.4.3.3

Checklist.Question: Is the EFR/ARFF unit actively participating in the DoD F&ES Certification Program?
Are IFSAC and Pro-Board certifications that are obtained from non-DoD entities sent to the DoD Administration center to be maintained in the DoD Look-up System?
Checklist.Reference: DoD F&ES Certification Program Procedural Guide, chap 6, par 6.

Checklist.Question: Does the unit train all EFR/ARFF personnel annually in the procedures for when to use and how to select the proper respirator, emergency evacuation, proper face piece fit, cleaning and storage, filter/cartridge change, service life, and inventory of all respirators? Is this training documented?
Does the EFR/ARFF unit maintain required emergency rescue equipment to accomplish the unit’s mission.
Are nitrogen cylinders for EFR/ARFF apparatus stored, maintained, equipped with pressure gauges, and hydrostatically tested?
Does the EFR/ARFF unit maintain a minimum ready stock of one vehicle/equipment load of AFFF, PKP, and Halon 1211 for each manned vehicle assigned?

Is each assigned firefighter outfitted with a complete set of personal protective equipment; to include trousers, coat, proximity gloves, extrication gloves, flash hood shroud, and cover, footwear, helmet with gold-coated face shield, respirator facepiece and regulator, and personal alert safety system?
Are advanced inspections of EFR/ARFF proximity ensembles conducted every six months ensuring inspection results are documented and remain on file for a period of two years?
Are EFR/ARFF Proximity Ensembles stored in IAW the reference?
Are sufficient filter-type breathing masks/ respirator available for use by personnel involved in mop-up, salvage or standby operations at crash sites involving composite materials?
Does the EFR/ARFF unit have a portable fire extinguisher inspection, maintenance, and hydrostatic test program and are records maintained for each extinguisher?
Checklist.Reference: NAVAIR 00-80R-14, chap 3, par 3.3.4, NFPA 10, chap 7, chap 8, and Annex 1

Checklist.Question: Does the activity have a Respiratory Protection Program in writing and are they in compliance?
Checklist.Reference: OPNAVINST 5100.19/5100.23 series, NFPA 1500, chap 7, par 7.10, OSHA 29 CFR par 1910.134

Checklist.Question: Has the Respiratory Protection Program Manager completed the Navy RPPM Course A-493-0072, OSHA training Institute Course 2220, 2225, or a 32 hour course meeting requirements outlined in OSHA 29 CFR 1910.134?
Checklist.Reference: NAVMC Directive 5100.8, page 13-12, sec 13008, par 3, OSHA 29 CFR par 1910.134

Checklist.Question: Is quantitative fit testing conducted and results recorded for all SCBA respirator users as required?

Do all respirators and canisters meet the National institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) recommendations for protection levels associated with hazard environment they will be used in and is the NIOSH label removed or cartridge out of date?
Are serviceability inspections performed and documented monthly on all respirators and equipment that are not in use by duty section personnel?
Are there any SCBA cylinders in service past their Hydrostatic Test date?
Are quarterly air samples taken on all compressors designed to fill SCBA air cylinders and is the Grade “D” air sample certificate current and maintained for the life of the compressor?
Is SCBA maintenance performed is accordance with manufactures recommendation?
Is a daily pre-operational inspection performed on all EFR/ARFF equipment in accordance with current technical manuals?
Is preventative maintenance performed properly on all rescue equipment in accordance with technical manuals/user manuals?

Are tools, equipment, and SCBA’s that are carried within enclosed seating areas of fire apparatus and support vehicles secured by a positive mechanical means of holding the items in a stowed position?
Are sufficient EFR/ARFF, Mobile Water Supply, Rescue, and Support Vehicles available to allow for maintenance,  firefighting operations and training?
Can the daily pre-operational inspection be verified through recordkeeping and observation for all EFR/ARFF vehicles in accordance with current technical manuals?
Can the proper preventative maintenance be verified through recordkeeping and observation for all assigned ARFF vehicles in accordance with technical manuals/user manuals?
Is the EFR/ARFF unit supported with a dedicated emergency fire and rescue radio network?
Are fixed based stations on the ARFF network installed in the air traffic control tower, aircraft fire and rescue alarm room, and the structural fire station?
Do all EFR/ARFF vehicles and support vehicles have mobile or portable transceivers?

Is a primary Aircraft Emergency Alarm Intercommunication System (direct wire) installed in the air traffic control tower, at each ARFF station, structural fire organization alarm room and airfield operations duty office?
Does the activity maintain a uniform alpha-numeric grid system and are maps available onboard all EFR/ARFF vehicles and located at all activities on the primary or secondary communications systems?
Are sufficient quantities of positive pressure Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) available to all firefighters required in an immediately dangerous to life or health (IDHL) environment?
Are routine inspections of the proximity ensembles conducted IAW with references?
Are EFR/ARFF proximity ensembles cleaned and decontaminated IAW the reference?
Does the activity maintain an Aircraft Fire/Mishap Response Plan and pre-mishap plans which includes the operational and functional details for on-station and off-station incidents?
Do drivers of EFR/ARFF vehicles ensure all persons on the vehicle are seated and secured with seatbelts in approved riding positions before moving the vehicle?
Can the EFR/ARFF unit demonstrate that they can meet the aggregate response time, if not does the unit staff an immediate response alert position?
Can the EFR/ARFF unit demonstrate their personnel accountability system during an emergency/simulated emergency response ?
When questioned, do EFR/ARFF personnel demonstrate a working knowledge of the uniform alphanumeric grid map system superimposed?
